The AHL and ECHL and to a less extent the IHL, are all minor league or semi professional leagues. In the AHL, players are typically assigned there by NHL teams and typically make 15% of their NHL salary if they have what's called a two-way contract (meaning they have an NHL salary and an AHL salary). Players that you see buried down in the minors, make their full NHL salary if they have a one-way deal (see: Gauthier, Denis by Philadelphia in 2007 among others). Players signed to AHL-only deals (i.e. no NHL rights) vary greatly. Players just coming out of juniors that were undrafted may see less than $40,000 per year (no lower than $28,000 IIRC). AHL veterans more likely in the $80,000 to $250,000 area. ECHL-only players typically make less than that. Usually in the $12,000 to $17,000 per year area (but other benefits are bestowed upon them, lodging, meal stipends, etc.). Deep vein thrombosis, or deep venous thrombosis, (DVT) is the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) within a deep vein, most commonly the legs. Nonspecific signs may include pain, swelling, redness, warmness, and engorged superficial veins. Pulmonary embolism, a potentially life-threatening complication, is caused by the detachment (embolization) of a clot that travels to the lungs. Together, DVT and pulmonary embolism constitute a single disease process known as venous thromboembolism.

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the formation of a blood clot within a deep vein. It most commonly affects leg veins, such as the femoral vein. Three factors are important in the formation of a blood clot within a deep veinâthese are the rate of blood flow, the thickness of the blood and qualities of the vessel wall. Classical signs of DVT include swelling, pain and redness of the affected area.
